text:
I'd like to introduce
our speaker today. Professor Michael Bernstein
is an Associate Professor

of Computer Science and the
STMicroelectronics Faculty Scholar at Stanford University.

He is a member of the
Human-Computer Interaction Group. And his research focuses on
the design of social computing

system. His research has won multiple
awards at various conferences and has also been featured on
The New York Times, The New

Scientist, WIRED,
and The Guardian. Michael has been recognized by
various scholarships and awards

for his research and activities. He holds a bachelor's
degree in Symbolic Systems

from Stanford University and
a master's and PhD degree in Computer Science from MIT.

And I'm sure you will enjoy
listening to him today. So with that, I'll turn
it over to Michael.

MICHAEL BERNSTEIN: All right. Hope you're all
having a great day. So yeah, that's right. My name is Michael, and
we're going to dive in.

We're going to talk a
bit about Design and AI and how that all sort
of meshes together

into the future of what
products and interactive systems might look like and what
it might not look like.

And how we actually understand
what's the right way to do this and what's the wrong
way to do this.

So just to give a little
bit of my own picture, I'm interested in how we build
interactive systems that bring

groups of people together. And this is often drawing
on artificial intelligence,

whether that is looking at
ways in which we can help use AI to make teams
better collaborators,

that we can understand how
crowdsourcing can help measure and benchmark AIs, building
some technical infrastructure,

looking at ways in
which ideation can be collectively experienced. This is the kind of
work that I spend

a lot of time thinking about. I build everything from sort
of algorithms up all the way to interactive systems and
products in the research world

that I live in. Now, what I'm here to talk about
today, what we want to discuss

is how basically we've
had this sea change. And I'm going to
start not assuming

much technical background here. Just to sort of-- we're going to start by talking
about how there's been this sea

change in artificial
intelligence or AI and how it's gotten much better. We're going to talk about
how that's translating

into organizations embedding
AI into their products, into their processes. And sort of this divergence
between sometimes this

goes spectacularly well and
sometimes it goes not quite as

well as you'd hope. And so the question
that we're kind of here to talk about is how do we make
sure that our experience is

more on the spectacular side
and less on the dumpster fire? So I always start
with a few terms, OK?

So when I talk about
artificial intelligence, we're talking about a
subfield of computer science

that's trying to automate
performance on tasks that we would normally consider to
require cognition of some sort

to solve. So we usually think of cognition
as residing within our brains, but there's a long
philosophical debate

we're going to
kind of align here to just sort of say
when we talk about AI, we're talking about
computers being

able to do things like say,
what's in this picture? What does the sentence mean? How do I get across
this room in order

to open the door as a robot? And so on. Now, AI has been trying to
do this for many, many years.

And what's been
happening over time has been a revolution through
an intersection of this

with the area of statistics. This is called machine learning. Machine learning
basically is not me

sitting in a room
saying, OK, I think this is how it should
learn to open the door. Instead, we provide
a lot of data.

And that data trains the
artificial intelligence to sort of build a statistical
model of the world.

And then it tries to act on it. So just it's like the
notion would be like just like how a human baby's
learning through experience,

it's never given rules. These machines are learning
through experience. One more term, deep learning.

You probably hear this thrown
around on the internet, on Twitter, and in academic
circles quite a bit.

This is essentially
one particular type of machine learning model. And it's a model that has
driven many of the improvements

in AI over the last decade. You see, when you look
at deep learning systems, you're often
looking at something

that has all of these circles
and lines connecting it, looking something like this. You can think of
it as you give it

some sort of input, which I'm
representing here as a vector. It's just a bunch of
different numbers or symbols

or whatever it would be. And it is going
to feed that input to a series of
interconnected nodes that

are learning weights,
which again, we're not going to really get into,
but it's sort of learning what to pay attention to.

And what ends up happening,
at the end of the day, your organization will
probably have something

along the lines of this. Now, this is not
always how it works. This is what's called
a supervised learning. But generally, many AI
applications sort of

have this general architecture. So you take a huge data
set of example inputs.

So let's say we're trying to-- let's say I'm Redfin. I'm trying to figure out for
each picture, what kind of room

is this? Is this a bedroom, a
hallway, is this a front shot of the home or what? So we get 10,000 or maybe
even many more images.

And then we produce what are
called labels for each example. And that's going to be the
thing that we wanted to learn,

like this is a bedroom,
this one's a hallway, this is a bathroom,
this is Michael's house. He could do better
to keep it up.

Whatever it would be. These labels are attached
to each of the inputs. So you have input, label,
input, label, input, label,

input, label. And then you have this
deep learning architecture.

So this is the AI that
tries to now learn how to go from one of the
inputs to one of the labels.

It's trying to predict
the label from the input. So it's given a picture it's
never seen before of the house,

it's going to try to say this
is a hallway or whatever. So we have all
sorts of examples.

These are colleagues
here at Stanford where on the upper
left is some work that Ranjay Krishna, a recent
PhD alumnus of my group

and Fei-Fei Li's group is
doing to try to say that this is a man flying a kite. That's what this
picture is looking at.

My colleague, Percy
Liang, has projects trying to fill in
blanks from sentences.

My colleagues Jeannette
Bohg and Dorsa Sadigh are learning how to
manipulate robot arms and so

on from human mappings. It's trying to learn when I move
the PlayStation controller, how should the robot be reacting?

These are examples
of inputs, outputs. And Andrew Ng, another
colleague at Stanford, I think

has put this quite well
in this HBR article. If you're trying to understand
what AI can and can't do, we're talking about progress
through a particular type

in which some kind of input
data is used to quickly generate some simple
response, like input,

picture, response,
is there a face? A, is there an English phrase.

Is the inputs an English phrase? The outputs a French
phrase to translate it? And what he basically says is
that if the typical person can

do this task with less
than a second of thought, we can probably automate
it with AI now or soon.

And I think this is not
always a perfect benchmark, but I think it's a pretty good
way, as you're considering

I would say if someone can
figure this out with about less than a second of a thought--
maybe they're an expert in the domain, they can glance
at it for 1 to 5 seconds,

be like, oh yeah,
that's the answer-- it's probably something
that you would be able to train an AI to do.

So people are doing this
to build AI-based products. So AI was in research
labs for many years.

And all of a sudden, it's
transforming many industries. So what's going on here? What do we do about this?

And what I want
to point out here is that the intersection
with us, with people is where AI kind of
lives or dies, right?

If it successfully
interfaces with people, then we make use of it.

And if it doesn't,
we abandon it. It's just like any technology. So I'll show a couple
of videos here. Hopefully you'll be able
to see in the window.

The first one is an example
from Cynthia Breazeal's group at the MIT personal robotics
group where again, the point is

not that we've got
some sort of magical AI that is incredibly intelligent. In fact, this robot is
not that intelligent.

But the ways in
which it communicates its intent and other
parts of its state to us

really become critical. Here's also Anca Dragan work. She's at UC Berkeley, does
really interesting work

in this space. Finding ways in which
the robot can communicate what it's likely to do.

So you can think, should
the robot be reaching as quickly as possible
for this thing or should it be kind
of wrapping around?

What is a legible? And what I mean
by legible or what she means by legible is what
is a movement that people

can predict what the
AI is going to do? So on one hand, we have AI
transforming industries.

We have Siri, Alexa, and so on
creating whole new verticals. In more prosaic ways,
you have Google auto

completing your
queries, finding ways to suggest ways you
might want to respond to that email in a friendly way.
But we have to think carefully. And this is work by Wendy Ju. She's at Cornell Tech.

And it's an interesting
example of what happens when we don't do this. So what you're about
to see is a video

of someone in a simulator of
an automated driving system. And at some point, the
automated driving system

is going to kind
of lose the thread. It's going to have to
hand driving control back

over to Nick here who's,
as you can probably tell, staring at his cell
phone at the time.

So this video is starting. And what I want you
to pay attention to is he's sitting there
staring at his phone,

not really paying
attention to driving. The AI says "Emergency." Nick grabs it, he's a little
confused, takes the control,

he swears, and almost
gets into an accident. So what's going on here is
that the AI was great until

the moment that it wasn't. And that handoff back to
the person, to the user, to the end user here
was really risky

and almost produced an accident. So we have to understand
these intersections.

Now, there are successes. So Netflix, as an example,
is using an AI technique known as recommender systems
to essentially be suggesting

what we should be looking at. Shaping what kinds of
stuff they choose to build.

So they're using what's
called a recommender system. Their inputs are what
other people like or view.

The thing is trying
to predict what other people will like or view. And it also produces
these clusters

of customers and clusters of
market segments and so on. Now, you also have something
like Stitch Fix, the--

I think this shirt might
actually be from Stitch Fix-- where they're personalizing
their online shopping

experience. Where again, the idea is based
on what other people would buy, what kind of clothes
might I be interested in?

So again, we see similar things. What are people
liking or buying? What other people
will like or buy.

You have the Google Assistant,
you have Siri, you have Alexa.

I'm sorry, if my saying the name
is activating your smart thing in your room because that
happens about half the time

when I give this talk. These are all using technologies
ranging from text to speech-- or excuse me, speech to
text and text to speech--

as well as interpreting what
it is you're asking for. So the inputs here
might look something

like just a wave file, like a
sound of what someone's saying. The output would be some
sort of transcription

and a structured request. And they have these rules
for handling the commands. That's sort of the architecture
of how this thing works.

Zillow, using computer vision
to improve property value estimates. So they're using
something called

computer vision, which is trying
to make sense of pictures. Again, deep learning on a
regression, meaning they're

trying to predict
a continuous value. So it's just same deal. Input is a picture, output,
how much did this thing

end up selling for? Here's Google creating something
to help with that problem

we've all had. Do you know that song that goes
da-da-da-da-da-da, na-na-na, oh yeah, the "Space Jam" DVD?

The issue here is
that you want to be able to hum something and
produce back what song that is.

So the inputs are
people humming, the outputs that they train
this thing on in some level is a melody, a song.

So even in the research
in medical worlds, you have products
looking at ways in which you can monitor your
glucose if you're diabetic.

So again, deep learning
regression, just trying to predict
a continuous value. Inputs, sensor values,
just stuff coming off

of your glucose sensor. Outputs, ground truth
measurements of glucose levels.

And so it's just trying to
map these things, right? It's saying input is here's
all the data we have,

output is this is what it should
have learned, your ground truth glucose level. Fraud detection, right?

So many of these examples. Again, activity sequences
on your website. Output, trying to predict
was this an anomaly?

We labeled the things
that were anomalies. Can you help us
find more of them? Ranking, so here I
am a social media

app like Facebook or Twitter. We want to know what
to put at the top. So you were going to
again, take these posts,

we're going to try to
predict where then we're going to rank with them. So I post something
like this on Facebook,

it takes all the features
that it thinks might matter-- how close Roni and I are,
whether this is a mobile phone

photo, whether you're
looking at this on your website or
your phone-- anything they think might matter. I'm just giving a
bunch of examples here.

That all gets thrown
into a big vector that the deep learning system
tries to work on top of

and trained to predict some
notion of engagement, which it will call a relevance score. So that might be,
will you like it?

Will you click it? Will you comment on it? This is what Facebook
is trying to learn.

So and what it does from this
is start to then rank the items. So it says, here are these
scores for every single thing

in your news feed. I'm just going to sort your
news feed by that score. OK, so that's a ton of examples.

What is this all about really? I'm going to use this term
intelligence augmentation.

I like the term because it's
an inversion of AI literally. So when we talk about AI
or artificial intelligence,

this is the opposite, IA,
intelligence augmentation, which is really a
reaction to this notion

that AI is going to take
over all our jobs, right? I think it is hopefully well
established at this point

that AI doesn't
just push out jobs, it replaces parts of jobs. It does push out some
jobs, in which case

I think we need to really
talk at a societal level about what that
pathway looks like.

But at the same time, in
many cases, what's actually happening is that AI is sort
of entering the job in ways

that we have to
figure out how we're going to integrate with it. And in the best case,
what you would hope for

is something that sort of
is a cognitive amplifier. Sort of like a
prosthesis for our brain that makes us smarter.

This here's a picture of Douglas
Engelbart, a Turing Award winner who envisioned
many of these ideas

originally when he was
at the Stanford Research Institute or SRI. It was all about trying to
push back on this notion

that AI is this entirely
autonomous thing that we're going to replace
human intelligence with artificial intelligence.

This vision of intelligence
augmentation or IA was one in which
these machines are being used to make us smarter.

Can we be less biased? Can we be more
predictive of the things that we want to
be predictive of?

Can we essentially be better at
what we're trying to achieve? That's the idea of
intelligence augmentation.

Now, this all sounds great,
but AI doesn't always work.

And as my colleague Eytan Adar
at the University of Michigan likes to point out-- I love this quote
of his-- never let

your UI or your user
interface write a check that your AI can't cash.

What he means by that
is that people end up building these
interfaces that are

sort of promising the world. And the AI ultimately
can't execute on it.

I think if you want to really
close-to-home example-- if you've ever
played with again,

your Siri or Alexa, your Google,
your whatever it would be--

the first time you
use it, you start trying to ask all sorts
of interesting things, like when's my aunt
coming to visit?

Or what's the weather
next Tuesday at 5:00 PM? And very quickly, you find out
that these systems are uber

brittle. That they don't work as
well as you would want. And what the research
literature shows

is that people then
sort of collapse into a small singularity of
things that they end up doing.

So like, oh OK, I'll just
ask it to set a timer, because I know it can do that.

So this user interface of
something like Siri or Alexa is saying, just talk to me,
I'll do whatever you want.

In reality, the AI
can't cash that check. So it becomes a
problematic thing.

So you have to make sure
you're not overreaching what the AI can actually do. So just to give a sense of
what products might actually

look like, here are some visions
from the research literature over the last 10 or so years.

Again, the research literature
tends to work 10, 20-- 5 to 25 years out.

So if you're a programmer,
you might not just imagine Codex, having OpenAI
write your code for you.

You might imagine being able to
write scripts that actually are using visual inputs so
that I can say something

like, hey, whenever I've got
this Google map that's tracking the bus routes or something,
what I want it to do

is just I want to say, hey,
whenever you find the bus inside of this area
of the New Haven map,

send me a text message. I don't know how to write
that in traditional code,

but I can certainly
take screenshots. And I can say, hey,
if you see this thing inside of this other
thing, let me know.

This is solving a real
human problem, at least it has been for me as I've had
to deal with commuter issues

over the course of my life. It's a simple script, but really
hard to explain without AI.

So you might have other
examples where here-- let's see if I can push
this slide to you--
let's see. OK, here we go.

So here's an example
of disaggregation, where imagine you
just wanted to have

one thing on the
outside of your house

that was just telling you how
much water is my sink using? How much water is my tub using? How much water is
my shower using?

Well normally, you'd have to
instrument every single piece of your house. But it turns out some folks at
the University of Washington

have found that whenever you
turn on your faucet or your tub or whatever, there are
very characteristic changes

in the water pressure
of your entire pipe system in your house. And through machine
learning, they can then identify when each
of your various utilities

is being used. And then turn that into-- the one use that I've
seen for those displays

that sometimes they try
to put on refrigerators that's showing you what
your water usage is like. You can imagine all sorts
of different visualizations

of your water usage just by
attaching a single sensor to kind of like the hose on
the outside of your house.

Here's an example for
accessibility reasons. This is-- imagine if our user
interfaces for our phones,

for our computers could adapt
to people based on their motor abilities.

So here you might see an
old school print dialog, but then below it,
you would see one

that was designed for someone
with limited motor dexterity. So it's made certain aspects
of the interface larger

and changed some of the things
from dropdowns to buttons and so on based on a model
of what this individual is

good and bad at doing. And this basically is
able to train off of this

to create way fewer errors. So imagine if our
systems could become more responsive to our own--

my own aging as I
start to lose my hair. So fashion mining, right?

Looking at ways in which
this might impact fashion. So imagine you want it
to be able to just say, I need an outfit
that sort of has

the following characteristics. It's sort of beachy
and tropical. Being able to model this and
suggest what that might look

like. If you're any sort
of graphic designer, imagine being able to-- as
these folks from MIT did--

create something that
can show you what people are paying attention to.

So it's estimating eye
gaze at a visual stimulus. So here's a poster. And as I move text around,
you can see in the video

here that it's actually
saying with the hot spots, here's what people are
going to attend to on this.

You notice sort of as I move
things around and change the weights of fonts
and so on, it's changing what people are
and are not paying attention

to in the poster. This is something that visual
designers usually can't do. But if we can start to model
through AI what people look at,

then we can maybe start sort
of getting out of our own head as designers a bit more.

Also in spaces like ubiquitous
computing and Internet of Things. Gesture recognition without
having tons of VR stuff

attached to us. Here's Gabe Cohn,
who was, at the time, working at Microsoft
Research, basically

showing that by just
paying attention to sort of the electromagnetic
stuff that's bouncing off of our light bulbs in
the rooms all the time,

it can start to
identify when I'm going through various gestures. You might imagine gesturing
to shut up the phone when it

rings or something if you're
in the middle of the talk, not that that's
ever happened to me.

Or how stressed you are. Imagine if your car could
detect if you were particularly

stressed out, and as a result,
could start to maybe be aware--

cut down external
noises and so on. This is Pablo Paredes
who demonstrating

that just by modeling
how sort of tense you are as you grip
the steering wheel, they can actually estimate
your levels of stress.

So drawing on some work from
my colleague Scott Klemmer, I want to talk a bit about
how we create products.

So this is going to
be sort of part 2. Part 1 was about, what's
coming down the pike?

What might this look like? Part 2 is, how do we
actually go about doing this? Now, I'm at Stanford.

At Stanford we teach this. This comes out of the
Stanford d.school. It's design thinking.

There's the sort of sets
of interrelated loops going from understanding to observing,
creating a point of view on what it is
you're trying to do,

ideating, prototyping,
and testing. And when you think
about it, this is intended to be useful
across essentially more or less

any interactive or
non-interactive product you might create. Now you throw AI into the mix.

And the question becomes, why
does this get so much harder? Why do we keep screwing up?

Which part of this
process is really tough? And for my money, it's
the prototyping stage.

Because we went from a world
in which you can sort of create

something that's static
with pen and paper for us to play with and
try out to something where

you have to get a full
fledged AI model work. And that's a problem
from the perspective of putting a bunch of
effort into something

that ends up being a dud. So when I talk
about a prototype, I mean something like this.

This is prototypes
of the original mouse that Microsoft-- the first
one that Microsoft put out.

Which was the mouse that
basically many of us who are elder millennials
like myself and older recognize as sort
of the first largely

successful commercial mouse. Wasn't the first one,
but it was the one that Microsoft had such
a large install base that it was essentially
the first one

that many people experienced. And what you can see
here in the background are all these prototypes
of different versions

of the mouse that
Microsoft tried along the way to the final product,
which you can see snaking its way through the middle.

And if you stare at
them, you can see how each prototype is a question. Each of these prototypes
is exploring some question

they're trying to answer. Like, what if what if the
mouse were kind of arced, like my hand, sort
of in a semicircle?

What if the buttons were
sort of very obviously off-set in different sizes? What if they had
different textures?

What if it kind of felt
like a bar of soap? What if it was really angular? They were playing with all
these different versions of it.

How would you do that
with an AI in which it would take tens of
hours, maybe even

months to create each
version of these things. So if we go with this
notion again from Scott

that a prototype is a rapid
approximation of a design idea that you're using
to gather feedback,

how do you gather feedback? Well traditionally, what I
would teach in an intro course is do this thing called
paper prototyping, where you

make your interface on paper. And then you sort of let them
click-- sort of tap on it

and you learn about it. So OK, now is this
app useful or not? s Now, the problem is,
how do you make a paper

app that's got an AI behind it? Now, it turns out they actually
asked this question back

in the '80s through something
that they ended up calling Wizard of Oz prototyping. And I think this is actually
becoming sort of back

in vogue in a way that we
haven't really seen in a while. The idea behind a
Wizard of Oz prototype

is that you have someone
kind of behind the curtain. You can see someone
here under the table who's effectively responsible
for turning the light on

and off. So the user is there playing
with this interactive room, so to speak, that appears
really intelligent.

When in reality,
essentially, there's someone behind the curtain
pretending to be the AI. And what this does
is it lets us kind

of mock in the
existence of the AI by doing it manually
instead of trying

to build the whole
thing only to find out that it won't be useful. So essentially, it says,
imagine we had this AI.

And then, what would
happen if it works? And that's what a Wizard
of Oz prototype does.

This essentially lets us play
kind of a game of time travel so that we can figure out
whether this system is actually

even worth building
in the first place. So making a Wizard
of Oz prototype

isn't too complicated. What we end up doing is starting
with the traditional stuff that we might do. We'd map out the scenarios,
the application flow.

We'd build this low fidelity
prototype, often again, using paper. And then we sort of develop
a contract or a script,

so to speak, that says
OK, wizard, human, person on my team-- whenever the user does
this, you should sort of

interpret it in
the following way and respond in
the following way. So it might mean that you'll-- this is the thing
that's later going

to be replaced with the AI. But for now, it's going to be
me or it's going to be Roni or it's going to be anyone else.

And the wizard is
going to basically just pretend that the AI
works pretty well enough.

How would it-- just
pretend, how might an AI react to this input? Maybe you should play with what
happens if it gets it wrong.

Understand maybe-- never
design assuming the AI is going to be perfect,
because it's not.

I promise you. So you then have a facilitator. This is someone who's
kind of guiding the user

through the experience. And then behind
the scenes, there is a wizard who's kind of
operating the interface.

They are playing the role
of the robot of the AI. And then as you
bring people in, they

can interact with your system. Maybe it's your new
maps directions or maybe it's your recommendations for
music you ought to listen to

or podcasts or whatever it
is that you're building. And the wizard is
more slow than an AI,

but comes in and can
operate the interface. And then you can talk to
them just like you would any other usability study.

So we start to see these
things actually even sometimes put into practice.

So this was a social Q&A app
called Aardvark, as reported on in the Wall
Street Journal, where

it was trying to connect people
with questions to people who could answer those questions.

And instead of
just spending years in Skunk Works trying to train
the AI to be perfect at this,

it actually started out with
this Wizard of Oz scheme. They would get questions
from the beta users

and they would just
manually route them. They'd be like, oh yeah,
it's totally a smart AI. Yeah, yeah,
definitely an AI doing this when they're sitting
there behind a computer screen

and routing things manually. So it was all entirely done to
make sure that the concept was

worthwhile. And as a side effect,
it produced a bunch of training data for
them to actually train

the final AI on top of it. Now, this is no panacea, right? It definitely is faster and
cheaper and more iterative.

It's more real than trying
to do something that's kind of a dead paper prototype. And you learn by
what happens when

the wizard is being pushed
into weird situations that you didn't expect. On the downside, it's not an AI.

So the errors that
it makes will be different than what an AI
might eventually be able to do. And it's slower, right?

It's kind of like, OK
now wait, the wizard is going to have to
think for a minute and shuffle some paper for you.

So it's not a perfect
approximation, but it's the thing
that you can do in three hours in an afternoon.

And I promise you, you
will learn much more in those three hours
than spending weeks

putting together an
initial version of the AI to do it yourself. So if you were going
to think about it,

you might try out a prototype. How would you prototype
an AI that knows-- that's like your cell phone
camera that's going to say,

you know what? That's a great photo,
Michael, but maybe you ought to move it down or
up or change the framing so

that you look good, right? How would you prototype
that with a Wizard of Oz? Well, you might have
someone holding just again,

a standard cell phone camera. And then you might
have the wizard, who knows something
about photo composition,

kind of over their shoulder--
wearing masks of course, because this is 2022, sadly--

and sort of making
those suggestions. And you can see whether
the person adopts them.

Do they understand it or not? Another example, an
energy plant safety system

using AI to identify anomalies
and alarm the technicians. So maybe you're working in
the energy industry already.

You go visit some folks
who are technicians. You have them sort go through
one of their training sessions.

And in one of the
training sessions, you're including an
additional pretend AI

and you see how
they react to it. They might say, well, I don't
know if I can trust this. It depends on what
signals it's looking at.

You start to learn what it is
that they need out of the AI before you finish building it.

Or an audio application
that's trying to predict what music I
want to play right now based

on my mood. This is sort of a classic
thing that every student wants to do at some point or another.

And again, what would
the wizard be doing? You grab someone
who has good taste

and is trying to
make suggestions. See how people react to that.

If they don't react to it
well with a pretty good human version, then
the AI version, whether it's better
or about the same,

also not going to
be reacted to well. Now, I want to show one other
sort of bleeding edge idea.

This is something we're
actually currently doing in my lab at Stanford. And it is, I think,
going to make

some substantial
changes to how we build and prototype AI systems. So this has to do with what are
called large language models.

You may have heard
of something called GPT-3 is one famous
version of this, but there are a number of them. Hugging Face and others
have really good ones.

The idea is that these
systems, for the first time, enable essentially a natural
language input to the AI

where you can sort of
tell it what you want and it will produce a response.

And you can sort of
craft nearly any AI that the AI could create. So here in some research
we've been doing,

we're interested in
creating, I don't know, we want an AI that can tell
whether this online comments

and say the Q&A for this
webinar is civil or incivil.

We don't want the incivil
stuff here, please be polite. So you just tell the
AI-- this is literally

what you would tell GPT-3,
the large language model. We're trying to determine
whether this forum comment is civil or incivil.

Imagine you read the
following comment on forum. Go shut yourself in
the room and think about what you just wrote.

So let's say you just posted
that to the chat in here. And then you write Q, would
you consider this comment

to be civil or incivil? A, this comment is-- and GPT-3 is expected
to finish the sentence.

I never trained this AI. There was no training. I didn't have to
generate 10,000 examples. I actually just read the
entire web, effectively,

or a curated version
of it, and learned to predict what
might happen next if it were given this prompt.

And it would produce
something like, say, incivil. Literally, just I spent five
minutes writing this prompt.

And all of a
sudden, I have an AI that I can sort of
use as a prototype. Is it going to be as good
as one that I fine tune

and make manually? Maybe not. But is it good enough
to kind of quickly

get a sense of whether
the AI can do this and how it'll behave and wire
it into a simple prototype?

Absolutely. I think this is going to
change the game, in my opinion. So given the results of
the prototype like this,

you iterate, right? So now, having tightened
this prototyping loop, we can go through
more iterations,

we can explore more ideas, and
we can avoid releasing duds.

So I think that leaves us with
the question of, what next,

right? Where are we going
to go from here? I think what we're going
to start to see is not--

we will see some entirely
new product categories, but I think probably
in aggregate, the bigger impact
is going to be AIs

being integrated into
many, many, many products that we use today to
sort of slightly enhance

the experience. To be slightly smarter, slightly
more user friendly, and so on. I hope that you use this not
to displace human intelligence,

but to augment it, right? To help us be smarter
at what we do. And so if I'm just
pulling this all together,

we have this
opportunity to think about how we're going
to design products that draw on everything from
sensor data to human language

to open-ended input. And that they're
typically going to produce fairly simple responses.

And if you fall into
that kind of category, you're in a space
where AI can help.

Now, at the end of the day--
and I think this is where a lot of the technologists miss it--

even the best AI is useless if
you're not solving a problem that people care about. So we actually have
to invert that was

I think one of the things I
was trying to get across today. You have to invert it
and start by asking, is this solving a
meaningful problem?

So we're prototyping
it before you invest all the time to create
these complicated deep learning models.

It's really seductive--
so seductive to just go train the thing.

I know it. I've been there. But it's almost
always the wrong idea. So instead, we use some sort
of prototyping technique

to see if we built this
and it worked pretty well, what would the
experience be like?

And if that's promising,
pursue it further. So I will wrap here. I wanted to leave lots
of time for Q&A. I'm

going to hand this back
off to my colleague Roni for a few minutes. And then we will engage
in some discussion,

which is always the fun part. SPEAKER: So one
thing that I think you mentioned early on,
Michael, in the talk

is how training the AI
systems can be quite complicated and
difficult. And I think

that as people think about
AI, one thing that's often overlooked is the
amount of data that's

needed in order to effectively
train these AI systems. And I was wondering, what
are some ways that you've

seen companies address
this need to get kind of massive amounts
of data in order to train?

Because if you have any examples
of effective ways to do that. MICHAEL BERNSTEIN: Sure.

Well, I think there
are two common models. One is when the company sort
of has its own ouroboros.

That is to say where it can
train on behavioral data that it already has access to.

Netflix can train on
whether you end up watching a show that it recommends. It can create little
experiments and just

say people watch this, but
not this or they started this and they abandoned it. Facebook has signals
like whether you

like a piece of content or not. Now, these behavioral metrics
are inevitably incomplete,

right? And as we've seen with
Facebook and others, when all you're doing is
trying to maximize engagement,

it can lead to some really
negative outcomes, right? So it can be a very effective
way of kind of bootstrapping,

but it inevitably kind of
hits some important limits and creates problematic
issues downstream.

Now, maybe there
are questions later. I have an entire
other talk I could give about sort of ethics and
product design of AI systems.

I'm going to put that in
a box for a moment other than saying there are ways
to do that better as well.

The second way that I
tend to see this happen is through manual labeling.

So the company will curate
some part of the data set

and then we'll go to either
some internal set of annotators that they've hired.

So many major tech
companies either have their own workforces-- Mary Gray has an excellent
book on this called Ghost Work

if you want to learn
about how this works. A common one today
is Appen, A-P-P-E-N,

that many companies will turn
to to get the data labeled for them. This is often referred to
as crowdsourcing or data

annotation. And they will go
and get something on the order of 10,000
or 100,000 of these items

that they grabbed annotated. And then ultimately, they go
try to train the model on it, look at the errors
that it makes,

try to go find more
examples in those spaces where the errors are, go label
more data there, and iterate.

There's no-- it's always
an iterative process. And it always takes more
time than you'd like.

SPEAKER: Perfect, thank you. So there are quite
a few questions

related to the prototyping and
the Wizard of Oz kind of idea. And I guess maybe let's
start with a question

that has to do with
prototyping in general. Basically, as I understood
your explanation

of the Wizard of
Oz prototype, we're trying to understand whether
an idea has any merit. Regardless of whether it's
an AI-based idea or not,

we're trying to
figure out if there is a need for it in the market
and how will users react to it.

And I guess that's
an idea that's probably true across any
product development activity.

How easy or difficult
is it in companies that you've seen to
pick up this idea

and really start to use
prototyping as a daily practice that they kind of
implement in their company?

What are some suggestions
for making this successful in a
company if you want

to make this kind of
a mindset that you're

pushing into the company? MICHAEL BERNSTEIN: Yeah. So this is-- it's a shift in
the culture of the company

to succeed at a
culture of prototyping. And just to sort of put as
fine a point on it as I can,

many companies have
brainstorming sessions. Decide in those internal
brainstorming sessions

what's going to be valuable. And then will basically put out
a bunch of engineering goals. And they'll build that
thing and they'll launch it.

If you're sort of design
thinky, prototypey in method, what you're
doing is you're instead

saying, OK, that does
seem like a great idea. What's our riskiest
aspect of that idea?

How do we build a prototype
that isolates and just reduces the risk in that dimension? So for example, we
once had a project

that was looking at trying to
see whether if we could use AIs to intelligently
suggest norm shifts in team

collaborations. Like, imagine a
little button, Slack, that's saying
something like, hey, I know this sounds a
little silly, but what

if you all sort of appointed
a leader for the next hour? Or I know this sounds
a little silly,

but what if you
all tried to sort be kind of a little extra
peppy for the next hour? Just try it.

And we're learning what's
working, what's not. Now, what we end
up doing is yeah, we could build this whole AI,
but at the end of the day,

we can convene some
teams and do this-- like the big risk is-- do people pay attention to this?

It's not, could
the AI learn this? Yeah, we could probably
learn something, right? But is this actually
going to change behavior,

is the big question. That's why we built the
prototype is the prototype let's strip away everything
except that biggest risk

and focus just entirely
on that vector. And we say OK, well, people
seem to adjust to it.

But now, there's a
different biggest risk. Would anyone ever
realistically spend enough time

with this system for
it to learn something? OK, well then for
that, the question that we need to prototype
the answer to is well,

how quickly could
it actually learn? And there we create a very
basic version of the AI and see how many--

in a simulation or
something like that, say how many iterations does
it need to learn something?

And so at every point, we're
just trying to kind of squish in this vector, squish in that
vector, squish in this vector. Each of those is a prototype.

And the prototypes are
sort of disposable. But over time, we
gain that confidence. If you want resources
for this kind of stuff,

I would look at Scott Klemmer's
online Coursera course, which teaches the sort of human
centered design principles

for interactive systems. Anything that comes out
of the Stanford d.school on the design thinking process.

IDEO inhabits much of this. It's really a mindset shift in
how you go about product design

and development.  SPEAKER: Wonderful. And so then if we kind of
continuing a little bit

on this prototyping
Wizard of Oz path, now if we're thinking
of a specific prototype to test an AI system, a
Wizard of Oz prototype

like you described,
can you describe the path of what happens after
you've done the prototype?

What are some
metrics that you use to determine whether the user
is interacting well with this

and it's worth continuing? And how would you take it to
the next stage in the process?

MICHAEL BERNSTEIN: Sure. In Bill Buxton's book,
Sketching User Experiences, he makes what I think is
an excellent, excellent

distinction between
getting the right design and getting the design right.

What he means by
that is that there's a difference between sort
of picking the right product to create and then
sort of iterating

your way toward the best
version of that product. Getting the right
design sort of is picking which mountain
you're going to-- which hill

you're going to climb. And getting the design
right is climbing that hill. So when you talk about metrics,
you have to think about first,

which of those two
things am I trying to do? Am I trying to say-- I talk about what's the risk.

Is there an existential
threat of whether people would actually make
use of this system? Then the metrics you're
actually paying attention

to are something
like, do they adopt it in their usage in
the task or whatever

or do they just ignore it? Or do they find it
grating or do they stop using it after 24 hours?

Whereas if you're trying to get
the design right and iterate, then it's actually you may
have some other metrics

that you would care about that
are a little bit more micro. And so I actually think
that those metrics

are selected based on what your
current goal or problem is. So I could give you essentially
someone's I would use,

but ultimately, what I would
do is I would start by asking, am I getting the
right design right now or am I getting the
design right, right now?

And if I'm getting the right
design, I'm trying to sort of-- what I'm trying
to essentially ask is, is this thing
worth pursuing at all

or should I change
it substantially? And if you're getting
the design right, then it's sort of like
you're asking questions more

like, where do
they get caught up? What kind of errors
are happening? Where are the bumps in the road?

You don't care about
the bumps in the road if you're not even sure if-- if
you haven't proven to yourself this is the right
thing to build.

But once you've decided
that it is, then yeah, the bumps matter a lot.

SPEAKER: That's great. So we've gotten a few
questions about the notion of intelligence
augmentation or IA.

And I wanted to see if you
can share some examples on how this might impact work.

So you said some folks are
worried that with AI, jobs are going to go away.

And it looks like through
your description of the IA, basically, we're looking
at helping people

perform their tasks better. Is that a right representation? And what else can you say about
its impact on future work?

MICHAEL BERNSTEIN: Sure. So if you want to
learn more about this, I would point you at my
colleague, Erik Brynjolfsson,

who's here at Stanford. And some work that
he and others have done I think make an astute
point that it's not that "jobs"

quote unquote are the-- jobs are not the
right unit of analysis for when you're considering
what AI will displace.

People used to say oh, we're
going to lose all teachers or something like this. We're not going to
lose all teachers.

But what will happen is
that tasks within jobs are going to get displaced. So you can ask something like,
is grading going to change?

Or is long haul trucking, just
like when you're in a straight

away, is that going to change? And I think the thing
to ask is, what's going to happen when this task
gets displaced from this job

by AI? Is it something where
now the worker is going to be forced to do more faster?

And is that an outcome we want? Is it doing something sort of
against their will in a sort

of tailorist point of view? Is it something where it's going
to help me in an information,

challenging environment--
like I don't know, I'm trying to make some product
decision-- make me smarter

at making that decision? That's the space where
I think we should be investing more energy. I think that there is so
much that just sort of tries

to picture AI as a black box
that's going to sort of fit in and sort of you pull out some
old other piece of the clock

and you put in the
shiny new part. I think that's totally wrong. I think instead, we want to
be thinking about what are

these ultimately in service of? Whose expertise can
be augmented here?

And I think that
essentially, it's about asking what are the tasks
that each of us in our jobs

are engaged in? And what is and is
not a good impedance match for that technology?

I think we'll find that
a lot of stuff isn't.

Look, I'm in a computer science
department I'm not a Luddite. But when there's so much
smoke around the Metaverse

and know crypto
stuff and AI, I think we have to ask,
what problem-- what

human problem is being solved? And make sure that there's-- I think that's what
tells us, what's

actually at the core of this? Or is the rest of it just
sort of technobabble?

SPEAKER: OK, so I guess
probably two final questions. So what, in your opinion, what
industry is moving the fastest

and has the most
investment in AI? And what are some
industries that could use more kind of
investment resources

and focus and benefit
from additional AI tools or products?

MICHAEL BERNSTEIN:
Well, the first half of that problem of that
question seems easier, so I'll start there, which is
basically the tech industry.

The tech industry for a long
time has been very data-driven. It knows how to do
data warehousing, it has the technical
expertise internally

to train these models. And so I think you saw
Silicon Valley adopting this

fairly early on, even when it
was less performant than it

was today. In terms of verticals
that have been behind,

I think a lot of
the challenge is that for many of
these verticals,

they less naturally have data. So if you think of many
applications in say,

sustainability, climate,
environment, sensing is really hard in
those environments.

You can't just go throw
smart dust through a forest to understand changes in
temperature and humidity

and flora and fauna. It's really tough. And so I have
colleagues at Stanford

who are working on this. And they end up using
things like satellite data to try to make inroads. And it's because there's
so little structured data.

So I think that
these are domains that could be truly transformed
if the data were there.

But the sensing layer kind
of remains a challenge.

I think that
another thing that-- sort of a slow
revolution that we will see that's starting
already, but will continue

is around basically
medicine, human health. Again, this is a
space where we are

very cautious about
deploying new interventions. And so I think that that's
less about technical issues--

those exist-- and more about
ethical issues, practice

issues, regulatory issues. I think we will see
it over time though.

SPEAKER: Great,
that's super helpful. OK, so I guess our last
question for today-- which is a big
question and probably

a topic for a different talk
or a lecture-- but we've spoken or we hear a lot said
about bias in AI.

What are some ways
to address that? What are some
things that you want to highlight as we
close out this talk

related to biases in AI systems? MICHAEL BERNSTEIN: Oh my gosh. I want to give a
whole other talk now.

OK, so I'll try to give the
shortest version of this that I can. AI-- saying that AI has
the possibility of creating

negative impacts on
our society, it's like, that's a horse
that's left the barn. It's so gone that the horse
has raced across state lines,

raced across the continent,
and gotten a shoe company scholarship. | a huge issue.

And there is some really
excellent work in communities looking at Fair ML.

Timnit Gebru and many
others have been involved. Ruha Benjamin, if
you look at her work.

Especially coming
out of many folks who are women and people of color. I strongly, strongly encourage
you to read their work--

not people who look like me-- on these issues. But there are
basically two things that I think are going on.

One is the models are picking up
on implicit biases in the data.

So an early example
of this had to do with recidivism prediction
in the Justice System.

Turns out there
are biases in who sort of winds up in the
Justice System and getting

picked up by crime
that has nothing to do with the person's
color, but the algorithms

learn that pattern. And then what
they're trying to do, these algorithms are
essentially trying

to say, look, we
want the algorithm to still work but we want
it to sort of have protected classes that it should
be equally treating,

say, whites and people of color. So it's sort of like saying, we
know the data coming into this

is problematic and
we're going to try to sort of boil it off a little
bit and try to fix the issue.

There's been a lot of
work in this space. I strongly, strongly
encourage you to check it out. Also, work that's just
trying to document

the issue like data sheets for
data sets or algorithm audits. Really good work.

The other sort of
issue here is how these things get
deployed in sort

of structurally racist ways. So you could have a
perfectly fair algorithm

and then hand it
off to a judge who decides conveniently
to ignore it when it sort of
disagrees with their gut.

My colleague, Angele
Christin here at Stanford has investigated this. And so from that
perspective, it's

totally incoherent to
focus only on removing the bias from the model itself.

We have to remember that
these models are getting embedded in products that
are embedded themselves in structurally racist
and sexist systems.

And so for that,
you have to sort of ask, how is this thing
going to be abused? What groups are going
to be harmed by this?

And again, I keep gesticulating
toward this being another talk. If you want to see
about it I recently

published a paper in the
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences that's
showing what we're doing here at Stanford to deal with that.

It's collaboratively
with Margaret Levi and political science,
ethicists, biomedical ethicists and so on.

And what we're essentially
doing is early projects are being reviewed by an
interdisciplinary panel

of experts asking, what are
the possible issues with this once this thing goes big? If it leaves the lab, if
it becomes commercialized,

gets used by an
authoritarian government. It's trying to foresee
what those issues might be and introduce mitigating
approaches early on long

before the horse
leaves the barn. So I think that
that's ultimately what we need as we're
talking about the impacts

of these things on society. So again, I have much
to say about this. Wasn't really designed
to be the topic

of this particular
presentation, but it is-- it's a thing that has to be
integrated into every product

development process
or you're going to end up with some really
embarrassing egg on your face.

And you're going to harm people. So that's one of the reasons
it's embarrassing, right? You didn't probably
didn't intend that.
